title: PinchRotate
content: Interaction component that allows the user to rotate the map by twisting with two fingers on a touch screen.

content: Get the underlying OpenLayers PinchRotate interaction instance.

title: PinchZoom
content: Interaction component that allows user to zoom the map by pinching with two fingers on a touch screen.

title: VectorTileLayer
content: Layer for vector tile data that is rendered client-side.

title: Vector
content: Provides a source of features for vector layers. Vector features provided by this source are suitable for editing.

content: The VectorSource instance or undefined if not yet created.

title: ImageLayer
content: Server-rendered images that are available for arbitrary extents and resolutions. It's a lightweight container for image sources.

title: OSM
content: Layer source for the OpenStreetMap tile server.

content: The underlying OSM instance

title: View
content: A View component represents a simple 2D view of the map.

title: View
content: This is the component to act upon to change the center, resolution, and rotation of the map.

title: View
content: Get the internal OpenLayers View instance

title: View
content: The internal OpenLayers View instance

title: Pointer
content: Base interaction component that calls user-defined functions on down, move and up events. This class also manages "drag sequences".

title: Pointer
content: When the handleDownEvent user function returns true a drag sequence is started. During a drag sequence the handleDragEvent user function is called on move events. The drag sequence ends when the handleUpEvent user function is called and returns false.

title: Pointer
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers PointerInteraction control instance.

title: Pointer
content: The PointerInteraction control instance

title: DragPan
content: Interaction component that allows the user to pan the map by dragging the map.

title: DragPan
content: This interaction is included in the maps by default.

title: DragPan
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers DragPan control instance.

title: DragPan
content: The DragPan control instance

title: DragRotate
content: Interaction component that allows the user to rotate the map by clicking and dragging on the map, normally combined with a condition that limits it to when the alt and shift keys are held down.

title: DragRotate
content: This interaction is only supported for mouse devices.

title: DragRotate
content: This interaction is included in the maps by default.

title: DragRotate
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers DragRotate control instance.

title: DragRotate
content: The DragRotate control instance

title: DragZoom
content: Interaction component that allows the user to zoom the map by clicking and dragging on the map, normally combined with a condition that limits it to when a key, shift by default, is held down.

title: DragZoom
content: To change the style of the box, use CSS and the .ol-dragzoom selector, or your custom one configured with wolClassName.

title: DragZoom
content: This interaction is included in the maps by default.

title: DragZoom
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers DragZoom control instance.

title: DragZoom
content: The DragZoom control instance

title: Map
content: The core component of Workletjs. This is the main container for all other Workletjs components. Usually you will use it together with wol-view component to setup zoom, center, projection and other view related properties for the map.

title: Map
content: A simple map with an OSM source.

title: Map
content: The wol-map element has its tabindex attribute set to "0", that makes it focusable. To focus the map element you can either navigate to it using the "tab" key or use the skip link. When the wol-map element is focused the + and - keys can be used to zoom in and out and the arrow keys can be used to pan.

title: Map
content: Clicking on the "Zoom in" and "Zoom out" buttons below the map zooms the map in and out. You can navigate to the buttons using the "tab" key, and press the "enter" key to trigger the zooming action.

title: ZoomToExtent
content: A button control which, when pressed, changes the map view to a specific extent. To style this control use the css selector .ol-zoom-extent.

title: ZoomToExtent
content: This example demonstrates how to use the ZoomToExtent Control component.

title: ZoomToExtent
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers ZoomToExtent instance.

title: ZoomToExtent
content: The ZoomToExtent instance

title: DoubleClickZoom
content: Interaction component that allows the user to zoom by double-clicking on the map.

title: DoubleClickZoom
content: A single interaction to zoom in/out by double-clicking.

title: DoubleClickZoom
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers DoubleClickZoom control instance.

title: DoubleClickZoom
content: The DoubleClickZoom control instance

title: Link
content: Interaction component that synchronizes the map state with the URL.

title: Link
content: The Link interaction allows you to synchronize the map state with the URL. The view center, zoom level, and rotation will be reflected in the URL as you navigate around the map. Layer visibility is also reflected in the URL. Reloading the page restores the map view state. The interaction can also be used to track other parts of your application state. For example, toggling the checkbox below updates the URL. Navigating back through history will also update the state of the checkbox.

title: Link
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers Link control instance.

title: Link
content: The Link control instance

title: MouseWheelZoom
content: Interaction component that allows the user to zoom the map by scrolling the mouse wheel.

title: MouseWheelZoom
content: This example shows how to zoom the map by scrolling the mouse wheel.

title: MouseWheelZoom
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers MouseWheelZoom control instance.

title: MouseWheelZoom
content: The MouseWheelZoom control instance

title: DblClickDragZoom
content: Interaction component that allows the user to zoom the map by double tap/click then drag up/down with one finger/left mouse.

title: DblClickDragZoom
content: A single interaction to zoom in/out by double clicking and dragging. On the second click, hold the mouse left button down and drag up or down to zoom in or out. Works also with touch devices.

title: DblClickDragZoom
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers DblClickDragZoom control instance.

title: DblClickDragZoom
content: The DblClickDragZoom control instance

title: DragAndDrop
content: Interaction component that handles input of vector data by drag and drop.

title: DragAndDrop
content: Example of using the drag-and-drop interaction. Drag and drop GPX, GeoJSON, IGC, KML, or TopoJSON files on to the map. There is no projection transform support, so this will only work with data in EPSG:4326 and EPSG:3857.

title: DragAndDrop
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers DragAndDrop control instance.

title: DragAndDrop
content: The DragAndDrop control instance

title: ScaleLine
content: A control displaying rough y-axis distances, calculated for the center of the viewport.

title: ScaleLine
content: Example of a scale line control.

title: ScaleLine
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers ScaleLine instance.

title: ScaleLine
content: The OpenLayers ScaleLine instance, or undefined if not yet created.

title: OverviewMap
content: Create a new control with a map acting as an overview map for another defined map.

title: OverviewMap
content: This example demonstrates the use of the OverviewMap control. Both the main map and the overview map are configured with layers using the same source. Please note that explicitly configuring layers for the overview map is mandatory.

title: OverviewMap
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers OverviewMap instance.

title: OverviewMap
content: The OverviewMap instance

title: Rotate
content: A button control to reset rotation to 0. To style this control use css selector .ol-rotate. A .ol-hidden css selector is added to the button when the rotation is 0.

title: Rotate
content: This example demonstrates how to use the Rotate control component.

title: Rotate
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers Rotate control instance.

title: Rotate
content: The Rotate control instance

title: WMTS
content: Layer source for tile data from WMTS servers.

title: WMTS
content: This example shows how to manually create the configuration for accessing a WMTS.

title: WMTS
content: Get the OpenLayers WMTS instance.

title: WMTS
content: The OpenLayers WMTS instance or undefined if not yet created.

title: Zoom
content: A control with 2 buttons, one for zoom in and one for zoom out. This control is one of the default controls of a map. To style this control use css selectors .ol-zoom-in and .ol-zoom-out.

title: Zoom
content: This example shows how to add a zoom control to a map.

title: Zoom
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers Zoom instance.

title: Zoom
content: The Zoom instance

title: ZoomSlider
content: A slider type of control for zooming.

title: ZoomSlider
content: This example shows how to add a zoom slider to a map and how to customize it.

title: ZoomSlider
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers ZoomSlider instance.

title: ZoomSlider
content: The ZoomSlider instance

title: BingMaps
content: Layer source for Bing Maps tile data. To use this source component you should get Bing Maps API key at https://www.bingmapsportal.com/.

title: BingMaps
content: When the Bing Maps tile service doesn't have tiles for a given resolution and region it returns "placeholder" tiles by default for Aerial and OrdnanceSurvey styles. To display stretched tiles instead of "placeholder" tiles at zoom levels where Bing Maps does not have tiles available, set the wolPlaceholderTiles property to false in the properties passed to the BingMaps source component.

title: BingMaps
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers BingMaps instance.

title: BingMaps
content: The BingMaps instance

title: ImageMapGuide
content: Source for images from Mapguide servers

title: ImageMapGuide
content: Example of a untiled MapGuide map.

title: ImageMapGuide
content: Get the OpenLayers ImageMapGuide source instance.

title: ImageMapGuide
content: The OpenLayers ImageMapGuide source instance or undefined if not yet created.

title: CartoDB
content: Layer source for the CartoDB Maps API.

title: CartoDB
content: A simple example with an anonymous cartodb map.

title: CartoDB
content: Get the OpenLayers CartoDB instance.

title: CartoDB
content: The OpenLayers CartoDB instance or undefined if not yet created.

title: TileJSON
content: Layer source for tile data in TileJSON format.

title: TileJSON
content: Example of a TileJSON layer.

title: TileJSON
content: Get the underlying TileJSON instance.

title: TileJSON
content: The TileJSON instance or undefined if not yet created.

title: TileDebug
content: A pseudo tile source, which does not fetch tiles from a server, but renders a grid outline for the tile grid/projection along with the coordinates for each tile. See Canvas Tiles for an example.

title: TileDebug
content: The black grid tiles are generated on the client with an HTML5 canvas. The displayed tile coordinates are the XYZ tile coordinates.

title: TileDebug
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers instance.

title: TileDebug
content: The TileDebug source instance or undefined if not yet created.

title: Zoomify
content: Layer source for tile data in Zoomify format (both Zoomify and Internet Imaging Protocol are supported).

title: Zoomify
content: Zoomify is a format for deep-zooming into high resolution images. This example shows how to use the Zoomify source with a pixel projection. Internet Imaging Protocol (IIP) with JTL extension is also handled.

title: Zoomify
content: Get the OpenLayers Zoomify instance.

title: Zoomify
content: The OpenLayers Zoomify instance or undefined if not yet created.

title: VectorTile
content: Component for layer sources providing vector data divided into a tile grid, to be used with VectorTileLayer component. Although this source receives tiles with vector features from the server, it is not meant for feature editing. Features are optimized for rendering, their geometries are clipped at or near tile boundaries and simplified for a view resolution.

title: VectorTile
content: Move your pointer over rendered features to display feature properties.

title: VectorTile
content: Get the underlying VectorTileSource instance.

title: VectorTile
content: The VectorTileSource instance or undefined if not initialized.

title: Group
content: A Collection of layers that are handled together.

title: Group
content: Example of a map with layer group.

title: Group
content: Get the OpenLayers LayerGroup instance.

title: Group
content: The OpenLayers LayerGroup instance

title: ImageStatic
content: A layer source for displaying a single, static image.

title: ImageStatic
content: This example uses a static image as a layer source. The map view is configured with a custom projection that translates image coordinates directly into map coordinates.

title: ImageStatic
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers Static instance.

title: ImageStatic
content: The OpenLayers Static instance (or undefined if not yet initialized)

title: Cluster
content: Layer source to cluster vector data. Works out of the box with point geometries. For other geometry types, or if not all geometries should be considered for clustering, a custom geometryFunction(wolGeometryFunction property) can be defined.

title: Cluster
content: This example shows how to do clustering on point features.

title: Cluster
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers Cluster instance.

title: Cluster
content: The Cluster instance or undefined if not yet created.

title: MousePosition
content: A control to show the 2D coordinates of the mouse cursor. By default, these are in the view projection, but can be in any supported projection. By default the control is shown in the top right corner of the map, but this can be changed by using the css selector .ol-mouse-position.

title: MousePosition
content: On touch devices, which usually do not have a mouse cursor, the coordinates of the currently touched position are shown.

title: MousePosition
content: Example of a mouse position control, outside the map.

title: MousePosition
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers MousePosition instance.

title: MousePosition
content: The MousePosition instance

title: XYZ
content: Layer source for tile data with URLs in a set XYZ format that are defined in a URL template.

title: XYZ
content: By default, this follows the widely-used Google grid where x 0 and y 0 are in the top left. Grids like TMS where x 0 and y 0 are in the bottom left can be used by using the {-y} placeholder in the URL template, so long as the source does not have a custom tile grid.

title: XYZ
content: The XYZ source component is used for tile data that is accessed through URLs that include a zoom level and tile grid x/y coordinates.

title: XYZ
content: Get the OpenLayers XYZ instance.

title: XYZ
content: The OpenLayers XYZ instance or undefined if not yet created.

title: DragBox
content: Interaction component that allows the user to draw a vector box by clicking and dragging on the map, normally combined with a condition that limits it to when the shift or other key is held down. This is used, for example, for zooming to a specific area of the map (see DragZoom and DragRotateAndZoom components).

title: DragBox
content: This example shows how to use a DragBox interaction component to select features. Features are selected using a select interaction component (Select), to recieve highlighting and apply filters (features with color #CC6767 are not selectable)

title: DragBox
content: Use Ctrl+Drag (Command+Drag on Mac) to draw boxes.

title: DragBox
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers DragBox control instance.

title: DragBox
content: The DragBox control instance

title: Translate
content: Interaction component for translating (moving) features. If you want to translate multiple features in a single action (for example, the collection used by a select interaction), bind feature collection to wolFeatures property.

title: Translate
content: This example demonstrates how the Translate and Select interaction component can be used together. Zoom in to an area of interest and click to select a feature or hold the Shift key and select multiple features. Then drag the features around to move them elsewhere on the map.

title: Translate
content: The Translate interaction instance.

title: Translate
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers Translate interaction instance.

title: Translate
content: The Translate interaction instance

title: VectorImageLayer
content: Vector data is rendered client-side, to an image. This layer component provides great performance during panning and zooming, but point symbols and texts are always rotated with the view and pixels are scaled during zoom animations.

title: VectorImageLayer
content: For more accurate rendering of vector data, use VectorLayer component instead.

title: VectorImageLayer
content: This example uses VectorImageLayer component for faster rendering during interaction and animations, at the cost of less accurate rendering.

title: VectorImageLayer
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers VectorImageLayer instance.

title: VectorImageLayer
content: The VectorImageLayer instance.

title: TileArcGISRest
content: Layer source for tile data from ArcGIS Rest services. Map and Image Services are supported.

title: TileArcGISRest
content: For cached ArcGIS services, better performance is available using the XYZ source component.

title: TileArcGISRest
content: This example shows how to use an ArcGIS REST MapService as tiles. This source type supports Map and Image Services. For cached ArcGIS services, better performance is available by using XYZ source component instead.

title: TileArcGISRest
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers TileArcGISRest instance.

title: TileArcGISRest
content: The TileArcGISRest instance

title: UTFGrid
content: Layer source for UTFGrid interaction data loaded from TileJSON format.

title: UTFGrid
content: Point to a country to see its name and flag.

title: UTFGrid
content: Tiles made with TileMill. Hosting on mapbox.com or with open-source TileServer.

title: UTFGrid
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers UTFGrid instance.

title: UTFGrid
content: The UTFGrid instance

title: TileLayer
content: For layer sources that provide pre-rendered, tiled images in grids that are organized by zoom levels for specific resolutions.

title: TileLayer
content: It should be used together with tiled source components like wol-source-xyz, wol-source-wmts, wol-source-osm, owl-source-bingmaps.

title: TileLayer
content: The map on the top preloads low resolution tiles. The map on the bottom does not use any preloading. Try zooming out and panning to see the difference.

title: TileLayer
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers TileLayer instance

title: TileLayer
content: The underlying OpenLayers TileLayer instance

title: WebGLVectorLayer
content: CRITICAL: WebGLVectorLayer component is experimental.This component is not part of the stable API and subject to change between releases. Consult the OpenLayers API documentation to see what is supported in the latest release.

title: WebGLVectorLayer
content: Layer optimized for rendering large vector datasets.

title: WebGLVectorLayer
content: This example uses the WebGLVectorLayer component to render a large ecoregion vector dataset loaded from a GeoJSON file.

title: WebGLVectorLayer
content: Get the underlying WebGLVectorLayer instance.

title: WebGLVectorLayer
content: The WebGLVectorLayer instance or undefined if not yet created.

title: VectorLayer
content: Vector data is rendered client-side, as vectors. This layer component provides most accurate rendering even during animations. Points and labels stay upright on rotated views.

title: VectorLayer
content: For very large amounts of vector data, performance may suffer during pan and zoom animations. In this case, try VectorImageLayer component.

title: VectorLayer
content: The countries are loaded from a GeoJSON file. Information about countries is shown on hover and click.

title: VectorLayer
content: Get the underlying VectorLayer instance.

title: VectorLayer
content: The VectorLayer instance or undefined if not yet created.

title: ImageArcGISRest
content: Layer source for data from ArcGIS Rest services providing single, untiled images. Useful when underlying map service has labels.

title: ImageArcGISRest
content: If underlying map service is not using labels, take advantage of image caching and use TileArcGISRest data source component.

title: ImageArcGISRest
content: This example shows how to use a dynamic ArcGIS REST MapService. This source type supports Map and Image Services. For dyamic ArcGIS services.

title: ImageArcGISRest
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers instance.

title: ImageArcGISRest
content: The OpenLayers ImageArcGISRest instance

title: Extent
content: Interaction component that allows the user to draw a vector box by clicking and dragging on the map. Once drawn, the vector box can be modified by dragging its vertices or edges.

title: Extent
content: This interaction is only supported for mouse devices.

title: Extent
content: This example shows how to use an Extent interaction component to draw a modifiable extent.

title: Extent
content: Use Shift+Drag to draw an extent. Shift+Drag on the corners or edges of the extent to resize it. Shift+Click off the extent to remove it.

title: Extent
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers Extent interaction instance.

title: Extent
content: The Extent interaction instance

title: Attribution
content: Control to show all the attributions associated with the layer sources in the map. This control is one of the default controls included in maps. By default it will show in the bottom right portion of the map, but this can be changed by using a css selector for .ol-attribution.

title: Attribution
content: When the map gets too small because of a resize, the attribution will be collapsed. This is because the wolCollapsible property is set to true if the width of the map gets smaller than 600 pixels.

title: Attribution
content: This example shows how to add an attribution that never disappears from the map. It works by passing a static string or HTML string into the attribution options, which is not linked to the layers. Click the 'Toggle layer' button to show that, even with no layers on, the static attribution remains on screen.

title: Attribution
content: Get the OpenLayers Attribution control instance.

title: Attribution
content: The Attribution control instance

title: Modify
content: Interaction component for modifying feature geometries. To modify features that have been added to an existing source, construct the modify interaction with the wolSource property. If you want to modify features in a collection (for example, the collection used by a Select interaction), construct the interaction with the wolFeatures property. The interaction must be constructed with either a wolSource or wolFeatures property.

title: Modify
content: Cartesian distance from the pointer is used to determine the features that will be modified. This means that geometries will only be considered for modification when they are within the configured wolPixelTolerance. For point geometries, the wolHitDetection property can be used to match their visual appearance.

title: Modify
content: By default, the interaction will allow deletion of vertices when the alt key is pressed. To configure the interaction with a different condition for deletion, use the wolDeleteCondition property.

title: Modify
content: This example demonstrates how the Modify and Select interaction components can be used together. Zoom in to an area of interest and select a feature for editing. Then drag points around to modify the feature. You can preserve topology by selecting multiple features before editing (Shift+Click to select multiple features).

title: Modify
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers Modify interaction instance.

title: Modify
content: The Modify interaction instance

title: DragRotateAndZoom
content: Interaction component that allows the user to zoom and rotate the map by clicking and dragging on the map. By default, this interaction is limited to when the shift key is held down.

title: DragRotateAndZoom
content: And this interaction is not included in the default interactions.

title: DragRotateAndZoom
content: This interaction is only supported for mouse devices.

title: DragRotateAndZoom
content: Shift+Drag to rotate and zoom the map around its center.

title: DragRotateAndZoom
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers DragRotateAndZoom control instance.

title: DragRotateAndZoom
content: The DragRotateAndZoom control instance

title: Getting Started
content: This guide will help you get started with @workletjs/ngx-openlayers in your Angular project.

title: Getting Started
content: This library depends on the following peer dependencies:

title: Getting Started
content: @angular/cdk: ^20.2.0ol: ^10.6.1

title: Getting Started
content: Make sure these dependencies are installed in your project.

title: Getting Started
content: Import the component modules you want to use into your component.

title: Getting Started
content: And import style file link in angular.json.

title: Getting Started
content: Here is a simple map with an OSM source.

title: OGCMapTile
content: Layer source for map tiles from an OGC API - Tiles service that provides "map" type tiles. The service must conform to at least the core (http://www.opengis.net/spec/ogcapi-tiles-1/1.0/conf/core) and tileset (http://www.opengis.net/spec/ogcapi-tiles-1/1.0/conf/tileset) conformance classes. For supporting the wolCollections property, the service must conform to the collections selection (http://www.opengis.net/spec/ogcapi-tiles-1/1.0/conf/collections-selection) conformance class.

title: OGCMapTile
content: The OGC API  Tiles specification describes how a service can provide map tiles.

title: OGCMapTile
content: The OGC API  Tiles specification describes how a service can provide map tiles.

title: OGCMapTile
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers OGCMapTile instance.

title: OGCMapTile
content: The OGCMapTile instance

title: HeatmapLayer
content: Layer for rendering vector data as a heatmap.

title: HeatmapLayer
content: This example parses a KML file and renders the features as a Heatmap layer.

title: HeatmapLayer
content: This example shows linear geometries rendered using a Heatmap layer. Data is AIS maritime traffic around Gothenburg transformed into GeoJSON, taken from this example.

title: HeatmapLayer
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers Heatmap instance

title: HeatmapLayer
content: The underlying OpenLayers Heatmap instance

title: DataTile
content: A source for typed array data tiles.

title: DataTile
content: This example generates RGBA tile data from scratch.

title: DataTile
content: This example shows a shaded relief rendering of elevation data from a PMTiles source.

title: DataTile
content: Get the underlying ol DataTileSource instance.

title: DataTile
content: The ol DataTileSource instance.

title: KeyboardPan
content: Interaction component that allows the user to pan the map using keyboard arrows.

title: KeyboardPan
content: By default, this is the map div, though you can change this with the wolKeyboardEventTarget property in Map component. document never loses focus but, for any other element, focus will have to be on, and returned to, this element if the keys are to function. See also KeyboardZoom component.

title: KeyboardPan
content: Note that, although this interaction is by default included in maps, the keys can only be used when browser focus is on the element to which the keyboard events are attached.

title: KeyboardPan
content: This example shows how to use the arrow keys to pan the map with the KeyboardPan interaction component.

title: KeyboardPan
content: The KeyboardPan interaction component is only activated when the wol-map element is focused.

title: KeyboardPan
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers KeyboardPan control instance.

title: KeyboardPan
content: The KeyboardPan control instance

title: Overlay
content: Overlay component creates an element that would be displayed over the map and attached to a single map location.

title: Overlay
content: Like Control components, Overlay components are visible widgets. Unlike Control components, they are not in a fixed position on the screen, but are tied to a geographical coordinate, so panning the map will move an Overlay but not a Control.

title: Overlay
content: This is a simple example of the Overlay component.

title: Overlay
content: Click on the map to get a popup. The popup is composed of a few basic elements: a container, a close button, and a place for the content. To anchor the popup to the map, an Overlay is created with the popup container. A listener is registered for the map's click event to display the popup, and another listener is set as the click handler for the close button to hide the popup.

title: Overlay
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers Overlay instance.

title: Overlay
content: The OpenLayers Overlay instance

title: KeyboardZoom
content: Interaction component that allows the user to zoom the map using keyboard + and -.

title: KeyboardZoom
content: By default, this is the map div, though you can change this with the wolKeyboardEventTarget property in Map component. document never loses focus but, for any other element, focus will have to be on, and returned to, this element if the keys are to function. See also KeyboardPan component.

title: KeyboardZoom
content: Note that, although this interaction is by default included in maps, the keys can only be used when browser focus is on the element to which the keyboard events are attached.

title: KeyboardZoom
content: This example shows how to use the + and - keys can be used to zoom in and out the map with the KeyboardZoom interaction component.

title: KeyboardZoom
content: The KeyboardZoom interaction component is only activated when the wol-map element is focused.

title: KeyboardZoom
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers KeyboardZoom control instance.

title: KeyboardZoom
content: The KeyboardZoom control instance

title: SentinelHub
content: A tile source that generates tiles using the Sentinel Hub Processing API. All of the constructor options are optional, however the source will not be ready for rendering until the wolAuth, wolData, and wolEvalscript properties are provided.

title: SentinelHub
content: If there are errors while configuring the source or fetching an access token, the wolChange event will be fired and the source state will be set to error. See the getError method for details on handling these errors.

title: SentinelHub
content: This example renders a tile layer with a source that uses the Sentinel Hub Processing API to generate tiles. The Processing API requires an access token. The form above can be used to provide an OAuth client id and secret. The default client id and secret used in this example is severely rate limited. For the example to perform well, you should register for your own client id and secret. With this information, the source will fetch an access token. If an accesss token is fetched by other means, the wolAuth property can be bind the token directly. See the Sentinel Hub authentication documentation for details.

title: SentinelHub
content: This example renders tiles from Sentinel Hub based on imagery in a user-selected date range. Changing the date picker to update wolData property with time range.

title: SentinelHub

title: GraticuleLayer
content: Layer that renders a grid for a coordinate system (currently only EPSG:4326 is supported).

title: GraticuleLayer
content: Note that the view projection must define both extent and worldExtent.

title: GraticuleLayer
content: This example shows how to add a graticule layer to a map.

title: GraticuleLayer
content: Example of a Sphere Mollweide map with a Graticule layer.

title: Image
content: Base component for sources providing a single image.

title: Image
content: Example of a map generated using a MapServer WMS, with an ImageSource and a createLoader function.

title: Image
content: You only need to set serverType if hidpi is true. On high-DPI screens, OpenLayers automatically calculates the map's pixelRatio and sends an additional MAP_RESOLUTION parameter to MapServer to ensure fonts and symbols render correctly.

title: Image
content: The Image source can be configured with service specific loaders. By default, the loader returns the image as decoded ImageBitmap. When using the ol/source/Image.load() function instead, SVG images will scale during zooming, because they will be used as HTMLImageElement directly instead of an ImageBitmap.

title: Image
content: Get the OpenLayers ImageSource instance.

title: Image
content: The OpenLayers ImageSource instance or undefined if not yet created.

title: Google
content: A tile layer source component that renders tiles from the Google Map Tiles API.

title: Google
content: After the component initialized, it takes properties that are bind to the component to create a session token. Refer to the documentation for additional details.

title: Google
content: This example demonstrates how to display tiles from Google's Map Tiles API in a map. To use the Google Map Tiles API, you need to set up a Google Cloud project and create an API key for your application. See the Map Tiles API documentation for instructions.

title: Google
content: The Google source component can be used with a tile layer and is configured by binding properties to the component that are used in creating the session token request for accessing the tiles. The wolMapType defaults to 'roadmap' and can be changed to any of the supported map types.

title: Google
content: When using the Google source component, please make sure you comply with the Google Map Tiles API Policies, by adding the Google logo in the bottom-left corner of the map. You can add the logo as a static image by using a custom OpenLayers control, as shown in the example below.

title: Google
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers Google instance.

title: Google

title: Coordinate
content: Angular pipes for processing and formatting geographic coordinates. These pipes wrap Coordinate manipulation functions from OpenLayers, making them easily accessible within Angular templates.

title: Coordinate
content: Add delta to coordinate. coordinate is modified in place and returned by the function.

title: Coordinate
content: Example:

title: Coordinate
content: Transforms the given Coordinate to a string using the given string template. The strings {x} and {y} in the template will be replaced with the first and second coordinate values respectively.

title: Coordinate
content: Rotate coordinate by angle. coordinate is modified in place and returned by the function.

title: Coordinate
content: Format a geographic coordinate with the hemisphere, degrees, minutes, and seconds.

title: Coordinate
content: Format a coordinate as a comma delimited string.

content: The ImageTile source is used for tile data that is accessed through URLs that include a zoom level and tile grid x/y coordinates.

title: ImageTile
content: ArcGIS REST tile services are supported by XYZ Source.

title: ImageTile
content: The ImageTile generates 256x256 pixel tiles by default. If the requested images are larger than that, they will be scaled to fit. This example uses 512x512 tiles, which are scaled to 256x256 for display.

title: OGCVectorTile
content: Layer source for map tiles from an OGC API - Tiles service that provides "vector" type tiles.

title: OGCVectorTile
content: The service must conform to at least the core and tileset conformance classes. For supporting the collections option, the service must conform to the collections selection conformance class.

title: OGCVectorTile
content: Vector tile sets may come in a variety of formats (e.g. GeoJSON, MVT). The wolFormat property is used to determine which of the advertised media types is used. If you need to force the use of a particular media type, you can provide the wolMediaType property.

title: OGCVectorTile
content: The OGC API  Tiles specification describes how a service can provide vector tiles.

title: OGCVectorTile
content: The OGC API  Tiles specification describes how a service can provide vector tiles.

title: StadiaMaps
content: Layer source for the Stadia Maps tile server.

title: StadiaMaps
content: Layers from Stadia Maps do not require an API key for localhost development or most production web deployments. See https://docs.stadiamaps.com/authentication/ for details.

title: StadiaMaps
content: Example showing the Alidade Smooth Dark theme from Stadia Maps, using the retina (HiDPI) tiles.

title: StadiaMaps
content: Two layer groups are composed: the watercolor base layer with the terrain labels from Stamen.

title: StadiaMaps
content: Layer name. Valid values: alidade_smooth, alidade_smooth_dark, outdoors, stamen_terrain, stamen_terrain_background, stamen_terrain_labels, stamen_terrain_lines, stamen_toner_background, stamen_toner, stamen_toner_labels, stamen_toner_lines, stamen_toner_lite, stamen_watercolor, and osm_bright.

title: Snap
content: Interaction component that handles snapping of vector features while modifying or drawing them. The features can come from a VectorSource or Collection Any interaction object that allows the user to interact with the features using the mouse can benefit from the snapping, as long as it is added before.

title: Snap
content: The snap interaction modifies map browser event coordinate and pixel properties to force the snap to occur to any interaction that uses them.

title: Snap
content: Example of using the Snap interaction component together with Draw and Modify interaction components. The Snap interaction component must be added last, as it needs to be the first to handle the pointermove event.

title: Snap
content: By default, the Snap interaction component snaps to edges ([wolEdge]="true") and vertices ([wolVertex]="true"). It can also be configured to snap to intersections between edges, which is done here with the [wolIntersection]="true" property.

title: Snap
content: The Snap interaction component can be configured with a custom segmenter for each geometry type. In this example, a custom LineString segmenter adds snapping to the midpoint of each segment.

title: Snap
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers Snap interaction instance.

title: Snap

title: Fullscreen
content: Provides a button that when clicked fills up the full screen with the map. The full screen source element is by default the element containing the map viewport unless overridden by providing the wolSource property. In which case, the dom element introduced using this parameter will be displayed in full screen.

title: Fullscreen
content: When in full screen mode, a close button is shown to exit full screen mode. The Fullscreen API is used to toggle the map in full screen mode.

title: Fullscreen
content: Click the control in the top right corner to go full screen. Click it again to exit full screen.

title: Fullscreen
content: If there is no button on the map, your browser does not support the Full Screen API.

title: Fullscreen
section: Full Screen Control with extended source element
content: Click the control in the top right corner to go full screen. Click it again to exit full screen.

title: Polygon
content: Polygon geometry component that is used with the Feature component to display a single polygon on the map.

title: Polygon
content: The Polygon instance created by this component.

title: Polygon
content: Emitted when the geometry changes.

title: Polygon
content: Array of linear rings that define the polygon. The first linear ring of the array defines the outer-boundary or surface of the polygon. Each subsequent linear ring defines a hole in the surface of the polygon. A linear ring is an array of vertices' coordinates where the first coordinate and the last are equivalent. (For internal use, flat coordinates in combination with wolLayout and wolEnds are also accepted.)

title: Polygon
content: Array of numbers representing the end indices of each linear ring in the flat coordinates array. Only used when wolCoordinates is provided as a flat array of numbers.

title: Polygon
content: Emitted when the geometry encounters an error.

title: Polygon
content: Layout of the geometry coordinates.

title: Polygon
content: Optional properties object to attach to the geometry.

title: Polygon

title: Raster
content: A source that transforms data from any number of input sources using an Operation function to transform input pixel values into output pixel values.

title: Raster
content: This example uses a Raster source component with MapTiler Terrain-RGB tiles to "flood" areas below the elevation shown on the sea level slider.

title: Raster
content: Input sources or layers. For vector data, use an VectorImage layer.

title: Raster
content: Add a source or layer to the sources collection.

content: The source or layer to add.

content: Remove a source or layer from the sources collection.

title: Feature
content: A component wrapped with Feature that is a vector object for geographic features with a geometry and other attribute properties, similar to the features in vector file formats like GeoJSON.

title: Feature
content: Typically, a feature component requires a single child Geometry component. At the same time, use a Style component to define the styling for Geometry.

title: Feature
content: Generic change event. Triggered when the revision counter is increased.

title: Feature
content: Generic error event. Triggered when an error occurs.

title: Feature
content: The default geometry for the feature. This will update the property with the name returned by wolGeometryName.

title: Feature
content: The property name to be used when getting the feature's default geometry. When calling getGeometry, the value of the property with this name will be returned.

title: Feature
content: The feature id. The feature id can be used with the getFeatureById method.

title: Feature
content: A collection of key-value pairs that will be set as the feature's properties.

title: Feature
content: Generic property change event. Triggered when a property is changed.

title: Feature
content: The style for the feature to override the layer style. This can be a single style object, an array of styles, or a function that takes a resolution and returns an array of styles. To unset the feature style, set the value to undefined.

title: Feature
content: Get the internal OpenLayers Feature instance

title: Feature
content: The internal OpenLayers Feature instance

title: Draw
content: Interaction component for drawing feature geometries.

title: Draw
content: Example of using the Draw interaction component. Select a geometry type from the dropdown above to start drawing. To finish drawing, click the last point. To activate freehand drawing for lines, polygons, and circles, hold the Shift key. To remove the last point of a line or polygon, press "Undo".

title: Draw
content: This demonstrates the use of the wolGeometryFunction property for the Draw interaction component. Select a shape type from the dropdown above to start drawing. To activate freehand drawing, hold the Shift key. Square drawing is achieved by using type: 'Circle' type with a geometryFunction that creates a 4-sided regular polygon instead of a circle. Box drawing uses type: 'Circle' with a geometryFunction that creates a box-shaped polygon instead of a circle. Star drawing uses a custom geometry function that converts a circle into a star using the center and radius provided by the draw interaction.

title: Draw
content: The Draw interaction component in this example uses a custom drawing style. Select a geometry type from the dropdown above to start drawing. To finish drawing, click the last point. To activate freehand drawing for lines, polygons, and circles, hold the Shift key.

title: Draw
content: This example demonstrates Draw interaction component in freehand mode. During freehand drawing, points are added while dragging. Set wolFreehand property as true to enable freehand mode. Note that freehand mode can be conditionally enabled by using the wolFreehandCondition property. For example to toggle freehand mode with the Shift key, set wolFreehandCondition property as shiftKeyOnly.

title: Draw
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers Draw control instance.

title: Draw
content: The Draw control instance

title: TileWMS
content: Layer source for tile data from WMS servers.

title: TileWMS
content: WMS can be used as a Tile layer, as shown here, or as an Image layer, as shown in the Single Image WMS example. Tiles can be cached, so the browser will not re-fetch data for areas that were viewed already. But there may be problems with repeated labels for WMS servers that are not aware of tiles, in which case single image WMS will produce better cartography.

title: TileWMS
content: By default, WMS tiles are reused across the 180 meridian. This behavior can be disabled by setting the wolWrapX property to false.

title: TileWMS
content: WMS can serve arbitrary tile sizes. This example uses a custom tile grid with non-square tiles.

title: TileWMS
content: Demonstrates smooth reloading of layers when changing the time dimension continuously. Data shown: IEM generated CONUS composite of NWS NEXRAD WSR-88D level III base reflectivity.

title: TileWMS
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers TileWMS instance.

title: TileWMS
content: The TileWMS instance

title: ImageWMS
content: Source component for WMS servers providing single, untiled images.

title: ImageWMS
content: Image sources fire events related to image loading. You can use template event bindings to subscribe to the wolImageLoadStart, wolImageLoadEnd, and wolImageLoadError events to monitor image loading progress. This example binds these events and renders an image loading progress bar at the bottom of the map. The progress bar is shown and hidden according to the map's wolLoadStart and wolLoadEnd events.

title: ImageWMS
content: WMS can be used as an Image layer, as shown here, or as a Tile layer, as shown in the Tiled WMS example. Tiles can be cached, so the browser will not re-fetch data for areas that were viewed already. But there may be problems with repeated labels for WMS servers that are not aware of tiles, in which case single image WMS will produce better cartography.

title: ImageWMS
content: This example shows how to trigger WMS GetFeatureInfo requests on click for a WMS image layer. Additionally layer.getData(pixel) is used to change the mouse pointer when hovering a non-transparent pixel on the map.

title: ImageWMS
content: With Proj4js integration, OpenLayers can transform coordinates between arbitrary projections.

title: ImageWMS
content: Get the OpenLayers ImageWMS instance.

title: ImageWMS
content: The OpenLayers ImageWMS instance or undefined if not yet created.

title: Proj
content: Angular pipe that converts geographic coordinates from longitude/latitude ([lon, lat] in degrees, EPSG:4326) to projected map coordinates using OpenLayers fromLonLat.

title: Proj
content: Use this pipe in templates to project coordinates for display or interaction with OpenLayers components. When the input is null or undefined, the pipe returns null for safe binding.

title: Proj
content: Example usage:

title: Proj
content: Angular pipe that transforms coordinates from a given projection to longitude/latitude (EPSG:4326).

title: Proj
content: This pipe wraps OpenLayers' toLonLat function to convert coordinates from any projection to WGS84 longitude/latitude coordinates. It handles null and undefined values gracefully.

title: Proj
content: Example usage:

title: Proj
content: Angular pipe that transforms a coordinate from source projection to destination projection. This returns a new coordinate (and does not modify the original). If there is no available transform between the two projection, the pipe will throw an error.

title: Proj
content: When the coordinate input is null or undefined, the pipe returns null for safe binding.

title: Proj
content: Example usage:

title: Proj
content: Angular pipe that transforms an extent from source projection to destination projection. This returns a new extent (and does not modify the original).

title: Proj
content: When the extent input is null or undefined, the pipe returns null for safe binding.

title: Proj
content: Example usage:

title: Select
content: Interaction component for selecting vector features. By default, selected features are styled differently, so this interaction can be used for visual highlighting, as well as selecting features for other actions, such as modification or output.

title: Select
content: There are three ways of controlling which features are selected:

title: Select
content: Using the browser event as defined by the condition and optionally the wolToggleCondition, wolAddCondition, wolRemoveCondition, and wolMulti properties.A wolLayers filter property.And a further feature filter using the wolFilter property.

title: Select
content: Choose between Single-click, Click, Hover and Alt+Click as the event type for selection in the combobox below. When using Single-click or Click you can hold the Shift key to toggle the feature in the selection.

title: Select
content: Note: when Single-click is used double-clicks won't select features. This in contrast to Click, where a double-click will both select the feature and zoom the map (because of the DoubleClickZoom interaction). Note that Single-click is less responsive than Click because of the delay it uses to detect double-clicks.

title: Select
content: In this example, a listener is registered for the Select interaction's select event in order to update the selection status above.

title: Select
content: In this example, the Select interaction reacts to the pointermove event for selection

title: Select
content: In this example, a listener is registered on the map's singleclick event to add and remove features from an array.

title: Select
content: Get the underlying OpenLayers Select interaction instance.

title: Select
content: The Select interaction instance

title: WebGLTileLayer
content: For layer sources that provide pre-rendered, tiled images in grids that are organized by zoom levels for specific resolutions.

title: WebGLTileLayer
content: This example uses WebGL to raster tiles on a map.

title: WebGLTileLayer
content: The prerender and postrender events on a WebGL tile layer can be used to manipulate the WebGL context before and after rendering. In this case, the gl.scissor() method is called to clip the top layer based on the position of a slider.

title: WebGLTileLayer
content: Note: This example is minimalist and works as there is only one WebGL layer rendered. That might works as well if the layers are drawn to different contexts. This does not apply to to several layers drawn to a single context, such as set with the 'className' property to 'canvas3d' on multiple layers. In such case, it's would be wise adapt your code using 'gl.clear' and other tweaks to the prerender/postrender event.

title: WebGLTileLayer
content: The wolStyle property of a WebGL tile layer accepts a color expression that can be used to modify pixel values before rendering. Here, RGB tiles representing elevation data are loaded and rendered so that values at or below sea level are blue, and values above sea level are transparent. The color expression operates on normalized pixel values ranging from 0 to 1. The band operator is used to select normalized values from a single band.

title: WebGLTileLayer
content: After converting the normalized RGB values to elevation, the case expression is used to pick colors to apply at a given elevation. Instead of using constant numeric values as the stops in the colors array, the var operator allows you to use a value that can be modified by your application. When the user drags the sea level slider, the wolVariables property updates. These updates contain the level style variable from the slider.

title: WebGLTileLayer
content: For the shaded relief, a single tiled source of elevation data is used as input. The shaded relief is calculated by the layer's wolStyle input property with a color expression. The style variables are updated when the user drags one of the sliders. The band operator is used to sample data from neighboring pixels for calculating slope and aspect, which is done with the ['band', bandIndex, xOffset, yOffset] syntax.

title: WebGLTileLayer
content: Variables used by the layer style.

title: WebGLTileLayer
content: Get the underlying WebGLTileLayer instance.

title: WebGLTileLayer
content: The WebGLTileLayer instance.

title: Introduction
content: Workletjs is a powerful Angular component library designed to provide a seamless and idiomatic integration with OpenLayers. It allows developers to build complex, interactive maps using declarative Angular components and directives, abstracting away much of the imperative boilerplate code typically associated with OpenLayers.

title: Introduction
content: Workletjs serves as a bridge between the Angular framework and the OpenLayers mapping engine. Instead of manually creating ol.Map, ol.View, and ol.layer.Tile instances and managing their state, you can use Angular components like

title: Introduction
content: , and

title: Introduction
content: This approach brings the full power of Angular's ecosystemdependency injection, change detection, and lifecycle hooksto your mapping applications.

title: Introduction
content: Declarative Syntax: Define your map structure using HTML templates.Angular Native: Built specifically for Angular, leveraging its core features.OpenLayers Integration: Full access to the robust capabilities of OpenLayers.Componentized: Modular components for maps, views, layers, sources, controls and interactions.Type Safe: Written in TypeScript with full type definitions.Reactive: Updates to Input properties automatically reflect on the map.

title: Introduction
content: OpenLayers is a powerful library, but using it in an Angular application can often lead to verbose and imperative code that is hard to maintain. Workletjs solves this by wrapping OpenLayers constructs into Angular components.

title: Introduction
content: Without Workletjs (Imperative):

title: Introduction
content: With Workletjs (Declarative):

title: Introduction
content: Workletjs is developed using the Nx monorepo architecture, ensuring scalability and maintainability. It is organized into packages that can be used independently or together.

title: Introduction
content: @workletjs/ngx-openlayers: The core package containing all map components.

title: Introduction
content: Workletjs is open-source software licensed under the MIT License.

title: GeoTIFF
content: A source for working with GeoTIFF data.

title: GeoTIFF
content: Note for users of the full build: The GeoTIFF source requires the geotiff.js library to be loaded as well.

title: GeoTIFF
content: This example demonstrates how data from a GeoTIFF in one projection can be displayed on a map with a different projection. For other source types, it is necessary to specify the source projection when it differs from the map view projection. In this example, information about the source projection is included in the GeoTIFF metadata, so it doesn't need to be specified in the application code.

title: GeoTIFF
content: The source.getView() method returns a promise that resolves after the GeoTIFF metadata has been fetched. This can be used to get the image projection information along with the image extent and center coordinates. The transform() function is used to transform the source imagery center coordinate when updating the view.

title: GeoTIFF
content: In some cases, a GeoTIFF may have external overviews. This example uses the overviews property to provide URL for a file containing external overviews.

title: GeoTIFF
content: Tiled data from a Cloud Optimized GeoTIFF (COG) can be rendered as a layer. In this example, a single 3-band GeoTIFF is used to render RGB data.

title: GeoTIFF
section: Cloud Optimized GeoTIFF (COG) from a Blob
content: Tiled data from a Cloud Optimized GeoTIFF (COG) can be rendered as a layer. In this example, a single 3-band GeoTIFF is used to render RGB data from a Blob.

title: GeoTIFF
content: The GeoTIFF layer in this example calculates the Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI) and Normalized Difference Water Index (NDWI) from two cloud-optimized Sentinel 2 GeoTIFFs: one with 10 m resolution and red and a near infrared bands, and one with 60 m resolution and a short wave infrared channel. The NDVI is shown as green, the NDWI as blue. The 4th band is the alpha band, which gets added when a source has a nodata value configured.

title: GeoTIFF
content: Get the OpenLayers GeoTIFF source instance.

title: GeoTIFF
content: The GeoTIFF source instance
